FacilityName: Helena Agri-Enterprises, LLC - Paul, ID Facility

_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Storage tank and ancillary process piping, valves, and transfer hose
_prev_prog_2.Description:
Covered Process 1: AA S&H:



The Terminal Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained employees as directed.  Although the process is not subject to the OSHA PSM rules, the Facility has incorporated this process into its PSM/RMPr combined management plan.  The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



This Facility stores and handles 29% ammonia concentrated solution in two 30,000-gallon dedicated aboveground storage tank (ASTs).  The process equipment includes two ASTs and ancillary process piping, valves, pump, and volume gauge.   



Aqua ammonia is transferred to the ASTs from a commercial tanker truck.  The commercial tanker truck operator performs the transfer of aqua ammonia into the AST.  Trained Facility Operator(s) are responsible for monitoring the AST and contents.  The Facility is responsible for training its Operators in accordance with the PSM/RMP Operating Procedures and maintaining the equipment in accordance with the PSM/RMP Mechanical Integrity Program.

_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Process piping, valves, pumps, and hoses
_prev_prog_2.Description:
Covered Process 2: Fertilizer Blending (AA):



The Terminal Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained employees as directed.  Although the process is not subject to the OSHA PSM rules, the Facility has incorporated this process into its PSM/RMPr combined management plan.  The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



Fertilizer products are produced by mixing 29% aqua ammonia with water and other ingredients.  The ingredients are transferred to one of two blenders by process piping that discharges into the dedicated blender. The process equipment includes: (1) process piping, valves, and liquid pump; and (2) one dedicated stationary blender and ancillary process piping, valves, liquid pumps, scale, and temperature gauges.  The blender does not have any storage capabilities for aqua ammonia. 



Trained Process Operators operate the covered process which includes the: (1) transfer of aqua ammonia, water, and other ingredients to the blender; (2) monitoring of flows and temperatures; and (3) transfer of product to storage.  The Facility is responsible for training its Operators in accordance with the PSM/RMP Operating Procedures and maintaining the equipment in accordance with the PSM/RMP Mechanical Integrity Program.  The fertilizer product is not subject to the RMP Rule.

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: The Facility has not received a railcar of NH3 as of this update
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Covered Process 3: Railcar S&H (NH3) 



The Terminal Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other Facility staff directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits.  



This Facility receives one or more railcars containing anhydrous ammonia from a Carrier and then secures and stores the railcar(s) on the Facility property.   The anhydrous ammonia is used to blend ammonium polyphosphate (APP) fertilizer.  After the anhydrous ammonia is removed from the railcar, the Facility releases the railcar back to the Carrier.  



Facility Process Operators are trained to receive, inspect, and release the railcar(s) in accordance with the Facility PSM/RMP Operating Procedures.  The Facility is not responsible for the maintenance of the railcar(s).  The Facility hires a qualified Contractor to transfer the anhydrous ammonia from the railcar(s) and blend the APP fertilizer (See Covered Process 4).

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Retained Owner/Operator of Mobile Pipe Reactor
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Owner/Operator has not Operated at this Facility as of this update.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Covered Process 4: APP Blending (NH3)



The Terminal Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other Facility staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. 



The Facility hires a qualified Contractor (A.K.A. Independent Fertilizer Reacting Contractor) to blend the APP fertilizer.  The Contractor owns and operates a Mobile Pipe Reactor (MPR) and is subject to the OSHA PSM rules.  



The Contractor connects the MPR to a railcar containing anhydrous ammonia, a railcar containing super phosphoric acid, and a water supply.  Covered process equipment includes the anhydrous ammonia railcar, nipple adaptors, emergency shutoff valves, transfer hoses, liquid pumps, and the mobile pipe reactor (MPR).  The Contractor transfers the anhydrous ammonia from the railcar and blends the APP fertilizer in accordance with its PSM Operating Procedures.  The IFRC maintains the MPR in accordance with its PSM Maintenance Procedures.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: This is a non-responding facility and it coordinates its response activities with the LEPC and local Fire Department. Notification information and procedures are provided in its Contingency Plan.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



This EPA RMP was prepared in accordance with the requirements of the Clean Air Act ? 112(r), OSHA 29 CFR ? 1910.119, and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) at 40 CFR ?68. The OSHA PSM and EPA Subpart D RMP standards are applicable to two of the covered processes operated at this Facility.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident. The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



The Facility is resubmitting the EPA RMP Registration to include the two covered processes that are being added to this Facility.  All accident prevention elements have been reviewed and/or updated.   



FACILITY



The operations at this Facility consist of chemical storage and handling, fertilizer blending, and distribution.  Two chemicals (i.e. aqua ammonia greater than 20% ammonia concentration and anhydrous ammonia) are stored and handled at quantities that exceed the regulatory threshold quantity.  Covered processes operated at this Facility include:



Covered Process 1: Aqua Ammonia (AA) Storage and Handling 

Covered Process 2: Fertilizer Blending (AA) 

Covered Process 3: Railcar Storage and Handling (NH3)

Covered Process 4: APP Blending (NH3)



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for all four (4) covered processes.  The worst case scenario release assumed that all the contents in the largest single vessel were released. For the aqua ammonia (i.e. representing Covered Processes 1 and 2), the worst case release was modeled as if the 30,000-gallon aqua ammonia aboveground storage tank (AST) fails for some reason and releases all contents inside of the secondary containment at the maximum temperature.  For the anhydrous ammonia (i.e. representing Covered Proce

sses 3 and 4), the worst case release was modeled as if the 34,000-gallon anhydrous ammonia railcar was punctured on the side at the ground level and the resulting release being a ground level horizontal jet at the maximum temperature. 



The alternative scenario for Covered Processes 1 and 2 assumes a release of aqua ammonia due to a transfer hose failure during a transfer event from either the commercial tanker truck to the AST, or from the AST to stationary Blender.  The alternative scenarios are different for Covered Processes 3 and 4.  For Covered Process 3 (i.e. Railcar Storage), the alternative consequence analysis assumes that an operator fails to fully close the vapor valve on the railcar.  For the Covered Process 4 (i.e. APP Blending), the alternative consequence analysis assumes that a liquid transfer hose is severed during the blending process.  The alternative scenario for Covered Process 4 considers active mitigation of the safety equipment (i.e. excess flow valve on the railcar; and emergency shutoff valves on the MPR), and operating procedures that the Facility and Contractor implement to safeguard against ammonia releases from transfer operations.    



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Terminal Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility. The Terminal Manager is assisted by other trained personnel as directed. The Terminal Manager is responsible for ensuring that its employees are properly trained in the implementation of the Program 2 and 3 Accident Prevention Program elements as related to their responsibilities.  The accident prevention program elements addressed in the PSM/RMP combined program includes: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



EMERGENCY

RESPONSE PROGRAM



This is a non-responding Facility. The Facility has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department. 



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at this Facility.



CONCLUSION



The Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The PSM/RMP will be updated as the Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes. 



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, and 6 of EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Facility.
